items.title: ZeroDivisionError when processing SVS files using deepzoom_tile.py
items.body:
## Context

**Issue type**: Bug 
**Operating system**: CentOS Linux release 7.6.1810 (Core)
**Platform**: 64-bit x86
**OpenSlide Python version** (`openslide.__version__`): 1.1.1 
**OpenSlide version** (`openslide.__library_version__`): 3.4.1
**Slide format**: SVS

## Details

Hi, 

I am getting a `ZeroDivisionError` when I try to tile an SVS image using `deepzoom_tile.py`: 

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/lib64/python3.6/multiprocessing/process.py", line 258, in _bootstrap
    self.run()
  File "deepzoom_tile.py", line 66, in run
    tile = dz.get_tile(level, address)
  File "/usr/local/lib64/python3.6/site-packages/openslide/deepzoom.py", line 158, in get_tile
    tile.thumbnail(z_size, Image.ANTIALIAS)
  File "/usr/local/lib64/python3.6/site-packages/PIL/Image.py", line 2279, in thumbnail
    y = round_aspect(x / aspect, key=lambda n: abs(aspect - x / n))
  File "/usr/local/lib64/python3.6/site-packages/PIL/Image.py", line 2272, in round_aspect
    return max(min(math.floor(number), math.ceil(number), key=key), 1)
  File "/usr/local/lib64/python3.6/site-packages/PIL/Image.py", line 2279, in <lambda>
    y = round_aspect(x / aspect, key=lambda n: abs(aspect - x / n))
ZeroDivisionError: division by zero
```

I was hoping someone could help me out. 

I have tried changing the `tile_size` and `overlap` values but no luck.

Some SVS files that I have work fine, others produce this error.

Thanks for any help.

items.title: Inconsistent output read_region() local vs server
items.body:
Hello,

I've noted an inconsistency when extracting patches from a .tiff image.
The attached images are the output of the same openslide.read_region() command,
One ran locally on a Mac computer and the other on a linux server. 

It looks like the 'y-0' reference point doesn't start at the actual 0,0 point, as the image is shifted down a little bit. Moreover the image extracted on the server is less detailed than the original image.

other strange phenomena are different level dimensions for the same slide
server side:
((164352, 84480), (82432, 42496), (41472, 21504), (20480, 10752), (10240, 5632), (5120, 3072), (2560, 1536), (1536, 1024), (1024, 512), (512, 512))

local:
((164352, 84480), (82176, 42240), (41088, 21120), (20544, 10560), (10272, 5280), (5136, 2640), (2568, 1320), (1284, 660), (642, 330), (321, 165))

The attached images are extracted on zoom level = 3 so the difference in dimensions could explain the reduction in image detail on the server side.

Moreover If I try to extract a large region near the bottom of the slide on the server I get the following error:


TIFFFillTile: 0: Invalid tile byte count, tile 53.
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "src/run_model.py", line 159, in <module>
    OS.extract_from_slide('output/test_rem_z5.png', 25600, 51200,5,(1000,1000))
  File "src/run_model.py", line 129, in extract_from_slide
    tile = self.slide.read_region((x, y), zoom_level, size)
  File "/env/lib/python3.6/site-packages/openslide/__init__.py", line 223, in read_region
    level, size[0], size[1])
  File "/env/lib/python3.6/site-packages/openslide/lowlevel.py", line 259, in read_region
    _read_region(slide, buf, x, y, level, w, h)
  File "/env/lib/python3.6/site-packages/openslide/lowlevel.py", line 196, in _check_error
    raise OpenSlideError(err)
openslide.lowlevel.OpenSlideError: TIFFRGBAImageGet failed

You would expect a corrupted .tiff image, but I copied the image from the server to my pc locally. 
So if the .tiff image would be corrupt, it shouldn't function on my pc locally.

On the server side the openslide package is run in a docker container, which installs all the following packages:
RUN apt-get update && apt-get -y install git libglib2.0-0 libsm6 curl libevent-dev gcc libxext6 libxrender-dev poppler-utils openslide-tools python-openslide python3-dev

Maybe some of these interfere with the openslide package.

Any ideas?

Thanks in advance!


![test_local](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16961387/71662305-43b8b200-2d51-11ea-8c5d-25dcdcbed367.png)
![test_rem](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16961387/71662310-4915fc80-2d51-11ea-8895-9a22ff4b4f18.png)

items.title: The read_region function behavior is odd.
items.body:
## Context

**Issue type** (bug report or feature request):  bug
**Operating system** (e.g. Fedora 24, Mac OS 10.11, Windows 10):  Ubuntu 18.04
**Platform** (e.g. 64-bit x86, 32-bit ARM): 64-bit x86
**OpenSlide Python version** (`openslide.__version__`): 1.1.1
**OpenSlide version** (`openslide.__library_version__`): 3.4.1
**Slide format** (e.g. SVS, NDPI, MRXS):  svs

## Details
I am using the python API of openslide packages to read some svs file. When I use the read_region function, sometimes it return a odd image.


I set the level 0 location and the specific level (other than 0) to the read_region function.
(ex. read_region(location=(at level 0 index), level=2, size=size)
When shifting the index by 1 pixel, I gives a odd image. (ex. Figure)

There is regularity in change, which matches the value of downsampling.
What is the cause?
I've reinstalled openslide, python but the problem persists. There are no problems when I use other pc (linux or windows) 

Thank you.

sample code
```python
with OpenSlide(wpath) as wsi:
    w,h = wsi.level_dimensions[0]
    x = np.random.randint(h)
    y = np.random.randint(w)
    diff = 7
    plt.figure(figsize=(diff,diff))
    for i in range(diff):
        for j in range(diff):
            plt.subplot(diff, diff, i*diff+j+1)
            im = wsi.read_region(location=(x+(i-diff//2),y-(j-diff//2)), level=2, size=(size,size))
            plt.imshow(im)
    plt.show()
```

![fig](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/13429694/65766515-38f4ec80-e166-11e9-9f55-72669f1e535a.png)

items.title: Feature was deprecated in 3.7 back in 2013
items.body:
FYI: Feature was deprecated in 3.7 back in 2013 and causes gcc compilation error which attempting to `pip install` this library (I'm using pip in Anaconda). A work around is to git clone, delete the line `Feature` and `features={...}` and then call `pip setup.py install` to install this package from source.

## Details

```python
import os
from setuptools import setup, Extension, Feature # delete Feature

# Load version string
_verfile = os.path.join(os.path.dirname(__file__), 'openslide', '_version.py')
with open(_verfile) as _fh:
    exec(_fh.read())

with open('README.rst') as _fh:
    _long_description = _fh.read()

setup(
    name='openslide-python',
    version=__version__,
    packages=[
        'openslide',
    ],
    features={ # delete features={...}
        'performance': Feature(
            'performance-enhancing extension module',
            standard=True,
            ext_modules=[
                Extension('openslide._convert', ['openslide/_convert.c']),
            ],
        ),
    },
```

Question: is there a way to use the performance-enhancing extension module as feature another way? Is this module useful?

items.title: Urgent: Facing issues with the Level-Dimensions in Leica .scn Images
items.body:
hello @bgilbert , @jaharkes 

## Context
Issue type (bug report or feature request): Bug
Operating system ( Windows ): Windows 8.1 and also Tried on Linux Server Machine (ppc64le)
Platform (64-bit):
OpenSlide Python version - 1.1.1:
OpenSlide version  - 3.4.1
Slide format  - .scn (Leica SCN Images)

## Details

I am facing issues regarding the Whole Slide Image for Leica .scn images. Whenever I use the slide.level_dimensions and slide.properties functions from the openslide python package to get information about the dimensions and the overall information about the slide properties, it gives incorrect information about the level dimensions. The information doesn't seem to match the information from the image.

My code details to reproduce to issue are:

import openslide
slide = openslide.OpenSlide('./nims-002.scn')
print("Level count: %d" % slide.level_count)
print("Level dimensions: " + str(slide.level_dimensions))
print("Properties: " + str(slide.properties))
print("Dimensions: " + str(slide.dimensions))

I am hereby attaching the details of 2 Whole Slide Image and their information from the slide.level_dimension and slide.properties function and those extracted from actual Whole Slide Images. The width and height at each and every level dont seem to match to the original scn image at all. As a result I get tiles with huge y-coordinates and few tiles that are completely black. For two different Whole Slide Images, slide.level_dimensions and slide.properties function gives same level values and same dimensions. How is it possible when both of them have different values of the levels and different dimensions all together?

Request you to kindly inspect the issue and let me know about it, as I am unable to proceed with my research. 

![a2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8632760/56159165-a01c4b80-5fe1-11e9-842d-49b932d04555.PNG)
[nims-002.txt](https://github.com/openslide/openslide-python/files/3081757/nims-002.txt)

![a4](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8632760/56159135-91359900-5fe1-11e9-9af7-b0caec89c674.PNG)
[nims-004.txt](https://github.com/openslide/openslide-python/files/3081754/nims-004.txt)

Regards,
Hitesha

Hello!

First of all, thank you for creating and supporting openslide. I started using it couple days ago and find it great!

Thing is, I'm working with and enormous dataset of *.TIF slides that is located at public FTP server. Furthermore, my future research is going to require access slides which are located in Amazon S3 data warehouse. So, the question is: is there any way to access files via FTP/HTTP or is it possible to implement such functionality in the nearest future?

Thank you again.

items.title: Performance bottleneck with Openslide and Openseadragon
items.body:
## Context

**Issue type** (bug report or feature request): performance issue
**Operating system** (e.g. Fedora 24, Mac OS 10.11, Windows 10):  Ubuntu 16.04
**Platform** (e.g. 64-bit x86, 32-bit ARM):  64bit x86. i7 7700k, 16gb ddr4 RAM
**OpenSlide Python version** (`openslide.__version__`): 1.1.1
**OpenSlide version** (`openslide.__library_version__`): 3.4.1
**Slide format** (e.g. SVS, NDPI, MRXS): svs

## Details

Hello,

I built a viewer based on the deepzoom example with openseadragon. I have several mounted folders using cifs, contains a lot of svs format images. I am currently testing it and the performance is terrible. it takes almost several minutes to load the image and when zooming it also takes a while to load. When I set the deepzoom server with local testing images it seems fine. 

I wonder what could be the bottleneck? the way openslide convert svs to dzi on the go? or it's simply bandwidth problem ( although highly unlikely as the file system is across the street and the bandwidth is never a issue with much heavier projects)? 

Any suggestion on improving the loading performance is greatly appreciated!

items.title: deepzoom module is not importable
items.body:
## Context

**Issue type** (bug report or feature request): bug
**Operating system** (e.g. Fedora 24, Mac OS 10.11, Windows 10):  MacOS 10.12.6
**Platform** (e.g. 64-bit x86, 32-bit ARM): 64-bit
**OpenSlide Python version** (`openslide.__version__`): '1.1.1'
**OpenSlide version** (`openslide.__library_version__`): 3.4.1 
**Slide format** (e.g. SVS, NDPI, MRXS):  NA

## Details
Running following when installed from `pip` or from github raises Not Found error:
```
import openslide
openslide.deepzoom.DeepZoomGenerator
openslide.deepzoom
```

## Fix:

Add `from openslide import deepzoom` after line 47 to `openslide/__init__.py`


openslide is already installed and I can view it under lib/python2.7/site-packages 

Please advise.

Thanks

**Platform** (64-bit): 
**OpenSlide version** (2016-7-17 64 bit release): 
**Slide format** (NA): 

## Details

    Traceback (most recent call last):
        File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
        File "C:\dev_res\python\python2_713\lib\site-packages\openslide\__init__.py", line 29, in <module>
            from openslide import lowlevel
        File "C:\dev_res\python\python2_713\lib\site-packages\openslide\lowlevel.py", line 41, in <module>
            _lib = cdll.LoadLibrary('libopenslide-0.dll')
        File "C:\dev_res\python\python2_713\lib\ctypes\__init__.py", line 440, in LoadLibrary
            return self._dlltype(name)
        File "C:\dev_res\python\python2_713\lib\ctypes\__init__.py", line 362, in __init__
            self._handle = _dlopen(self._name, mode)

I installed the OpenSlide binaries and added the bin folder to my system path. I then installed python-openslide using pip. I tried same workflow with Python 3.5.3 and encountered the same problem. Interestingly, when I tested this with the 32-bit version of Python(2.7)/OpenSlide I did not have this issue. However, I have a 64-bit machine and would prefer to use the 64-bit versions.

Not sure if this is a bug or is specific to my configuration. Any help would be greatly appreciated!

items.title: openslide acting different in python 2.7.10 and 2.7.6
items.body:
## Context

**Issue type** (bug report or feature request): 
**Operating system** (e.g. Fedora 24, Mac OS 10.11, Windows 10): 
**Platform** (e.g. 64-bit x86, 32-bit ARM): 
**OpenSlide Python version** (`openslide.__version__`): 
**OpenSlide version** (`openslide.__library_version__`): 
**Slide format** (e.g. SVS, NDPI, MRXS): 

## Details

So i have a tiff image and am opening this image into level 6 on openslide but the width and height are different in python 2.7.10 and 2.7.6

Here is the code


        tumor_file = openslide.OpenSlide(tumor_img) 
        region_x, region_y = tumor_file.level_dimensions[6]

on python 2.7.10 region_x , region_y = 1472 1120
on python 2.7.6 region_x, region _y = 1536, 1536

items.title: Integer division bug
items.body:
Hello,

This snippet on line 85 of openslide.deepzoom.py
`z_size = tuple(max(1, int(math.ceil(z / 2))) for z in z_size)`

should almost definitely read
`z_size = tuple(max(1, int(math.ceil(z / 2.0))) for z in z_size)`

In the case of images where either dimension is not a power of 2 the first line causes rounding errors which result in the incorrect number of blocks.

Any pointers on how to solve this or is it simply not possible with the python bindings?

items.title: Create drop-in example/a library for using with apache webserver
items.body: Deepzoom server is nice, but if anybody would like to use it in some production enviroment - the only solution is static version. Some kind of mod_wsgi version would be awesome.

items.title: Switch examples to openseadragon/openseadragon
items.body: [openseadragon/openseadragon](https://github.com/openseadragon/openseadragon) contains many updates vs. the CodePlex version and is actively maintained.

items.title: Segfault accessing property map after OpenSlide object freed
items.body:
`_PropertyMap` and `_AssociatedImageMap` objects can outlive their parent `OpenSlide`.  Attempts to use them will access a `lowlevel._OpenSlide` handle which has already been closed.

Handle cleanup via `__del__` should happen in the `_OpenSlide` object, not in `OpenSlide`.  This doesn't solve the `OpenSlide.close()` case, so `_OpenSlide` objects should know when they have been closed and throw an exception if they are used again.

items.title: Switching between associated images causes performance loss
items.body:
If you switch between the Slide and other associated images in a statically tiled slide, you'll notice that performance worsens. This is because multiple seadragons are constructed but not destroyed. Timers seem to keep firing, which slows down performance.

This can be easily verified in the Timeline in a webkit browser.

items.title: Support Windows
items.body: openslide.lowlevel may not correctly load the C library on Windows.  Check this.

items.title: Support Python 3
items.body: Once PIL supports Python 3, we should too.
